Description: https://youtube.com/shorts/qsyXkDmITlk?feature=share The walking foot is often described as a sewing machine foot that evenly feeds layers of fabric and batting through the machine while quilting. The foot grips onto the top layer of fabric and helps move it under the needle at the same pace that the machine's feed dogs are moving the bottom layer of fabric. This amazing foot have large plastic wheels inside them to help keep all layers even so you get nice, flat edges. The walking foot keeps fabric and batting layers together while quilting. It is your best friend when machine quilting straight lines and large, gently curved lines. Good for sewing multiple layers of fabrics without skipped stitches, for example when sewing peplum dresses.

Description:
A compensating presser foot is used for sewing even stitches along the edge of fabric, top stitching, and more: 
  • Sewing even stitches
    A compensating foot can create even stitches 1/16 in from the edge of the fabric. 
  • Top stitching
    A compensating foot is useful for top stitching close to the edge of a zipper or bag. 
  • Sewing through different thicknesses
    A compensating foot can go over different thicknesses of fabric. The larger toe of the foot sits against the feed dogs while the fabric sits under the foot. 
  • Stabilizing stitching
    A compensating foot can stabilize stitching 1.5 mm to the right or left of a thick seam. 
  • Using as a seam guide
    A compensating foot can be used with a gauge to get an accurate seam allowance.
